cons: Psychiatry has low respect in the hospital in general - not exactly the residency's fault - but the department is definitely on the lower end of the hospital's priority list and it definitely shows whether it's the "historic" (read: decrepit) building the residents and faculty work out of or the fact that its inpatient unit was axed because it wasn't "bringing in enough money".

job_title: Specialty Pharmacy Technician in Augusta, GA
pros: 401k, insurance, guaranteed 40 hours a week. Good learning experience
cons:
They do not give consistent annual raises.
They no longer give bonuses. 
Moving up within the company is all about who you know and not what you actually know. 
There is an attendance points system.
If you forget to clock in or out you get .25 point.
If you’re late to work you get .50point. 
If you call out you get 1 point.
Call out during holidays are 2 points.
Once you reach 8 points you get fired.

pros: They are a Large Employer.

pros:
Pros are only working 3 days out of the week, you have the freedom to get other things in life done or to work overtime if you choose. 
The excitement of the ER, if you like those types of things. You get to see up close what goes on with patients and treatment. You get to build relationships with Nurses, Doctors, Techs, EMT's everyone on the ER floor.
cons:
In the ER it is ALOT of walking. Be prepared to hit 6k step on a slow/normal day and 13-16k on a busy day. 
Teamwork in the ER registration department is still a work in progress, I think everywhere you go you will always have those people who are difficult and refuse to work together.

job_title: Environmental Services Technician in Augusta, GA
pros: Full time hours, weekends off, consistent schedule. Benefits are inexpensive.
cons: Issues with coworkers/management are never resolved. Some buildings have a toxic work environment and disputes between coworkers or management is fairly common. Upper management pretends to care or attempt to fix problems by sweeping them under the rug, leading to retaliation. Difficult to get things done due to lack of tools that aren't broken or have been lent to other buildings. Takes forever to hire people and pretty much stays understaffed. You have to pay for parking and in most cases, the rate isn't automatically reduced if you're making below the threshold. You also can't opt out of paying for the retirement package.

review_title: Great institution on its way up......
pros: Strong focus on research, teaching innovation and excellence, and community involvement.  Many supervisors in the University have a strong desire to improve current operations and programs and be innovative.  The new president is working hard to solidify the brand and bring consistency and harmony to unite the campuses.  Many departments are striving to contribute to and take advantage of the knowledge in their corresponding discipline areas in the community, inviting guest speakers into their classroom and providing rich internship opportunities for students, as well as events that join academia and the professional community.
cons: Massive change with the consolidation of MCG and GRU years ago is still affecting the school.  Administration has a large task in front of them, uniting a hospital and a traditional college.  A few departments need more efficient processes internally and additional channels of communication externally, because they affect other departments.  Parking seems to be a big problem, especially on the Health Sciences campus.

job_title: Utilization Review Nurse in Augusta, GA
pros: The pay is very good.
cons: The company will not let you work from home.

pros: Great learning opportunities available here.
cons: Poor departmental leadership in the department I work in.

pros: A lot of free time to work autonomously. Pretty much an unlimited budget for design, tools, software, equipment, conferences, trips, etc.  I would recommend working here to gain design experience, communications experience, but don't plan to stay here for more than a year unless you want to become a doormat to the spoiled girls in the management team. But if you like social cliques, then you will probably love it here.
cons: Very top-heavy management, no justification for the number of managers to ratio of employees. Within that top-heavy structure, several managers/ directors were promoted at very early ages, and I don't believe their quality of work can stand alone, nor do I see them as effective leaders. They are quick to delegate large projects, then retreat to their offices with closed doors. Many of them refuse to use the phone, and communicate with people in the office via email.  They are very good at looking busy or burdening their calendars with meetings that they blow off anyway.

pros: Upper Management was very helpful. They were all a very wonderful, spirited staff that loved to have a family environment. The other student technicians were like a family and all very helpful when things popped up. It was easy to work with school schedules and if school was becoming an obstacle, they tried their best to let you study and pick up hours later on.
cons: Some times management was very contradicting. They strictly told the students what their job was, but at the end of the day if on slacked the other picked up their slack. There were times that management could have had better things to say about people who rented out the theatre. At times things felt rushed and it was hard to fully grasp the procedures because everything was so time sensitive.

pros: Most employees are very friendly. And, if you do your work, there is little chance you'll be layed off, so there is job security. The pay is usually better compared to other hospitals, similar jobs.
cons: Human Resources instituted a new point system for when you are late or can't come in. After so many points, you get written up and then fired. You can have laboratory-confirmed flu, get sent home, and STILL get points. And, the review system is so ridiculous, and a total waste of time. Most employees think it's a joke.

pros: Has a more attractice benefits plan particularly the health plan is affordable, no out of pocket and easy access to the MCGHI team of specialists.
cons: Stody management practices. A CEO that is formidable both in personal and work place philosphy. Autocratic leadership style. Not a contemporary employer in family/worklife balance. The first month I was there I worked 65 hours a week. I kept thinking it was me-I just worked too hard, cared to much. Then 3 months later I began to see how many people used small roll around (the airline carry on type) suitecases to take work home. It's sad.

review_title: Paul Blart would be proud to call this place home
pros: The only pros working for them was getting to work UGA/GT football games.  THAT WAS IT!
cons:
The list is a mile long.
Horrible leadership.
Everyone out for themselves.
Nobody is trustworthy.
Be prepared to not have any life outside of work because they refuse to go to 12 hour shifts and expect you to be ok with working decades with only two days off and those days are typically during middle of week and you won't get weekends off unless you are a serious brown-noser or female. 
They have decided to start hiring 18 year olds with no life experience or mental capacity to understand what they are doing and let the power of the gun and badge go to their heads.  
Chief is a joke and the Majors and other supervisors are always out to find dirt on everyone so they can use it to their advantage if something goes wrong or they need something.

pros: Opportunity to see a lot of pathology and abnormal cases. Many of the doctors are friendly. Willing to hire new graduates. No vesting period for retirement account.
cons: High stress, low pay, poor parking situation, low employee morale. Constant student instruction from high school, undergrad, medical school, and resident training- can be exhausting at times. 30 minute lunches you have to clock in and out for. If you are one minute late clocking back in your hours will be short. Large crowds of family members are able to come in for patient exams. Mentally taxing.

review_title: Staff nurse at ASMP thru AU
pros:
Working with inmates.
Rarely  have families in the facility. No patient satisfaction survey scores to worry about. Never sent Home for low census. Some security staff are extremely helpful and will make your job easier, and if a patient is acting out they will handle it instead of nursing staff.
cons: Management, if you need help they will not support you. Some security staff will  purposely lock you into rooms with inmates and not let you out in a timely manner. Cleanliness. Outdated equipment. Still using paper charting.

review_title: This position being good or bad depends on the department you work for.
pros: GRU employs a wonderful variety of people from different cultures. Every day is different and interesting.  The familial atmosphere helps new employees acclimate quickly and makes them feel as if they are truly apart of something significant.
cons: As a state funded facility there is never enough money in the budget to hire the amount of employees needed.  Everyone tends to be overworked.  Your annual reviews etc. tends to be in the hands of one individual in power.

job_title: Senior Rad Tech in Augusta, GA
pros: They offer great salaries and some of the best health benefits
cons: Too many managers doing the same job and not willing to help the staff when we are short of help.

pros: Very friendly but professional atmosphere. Faculty and staff were very helpful, and I've learned a lot from them. Provided many opportunities for personal and professional growth which I was able to pursue.
cons: Relatively smaller size compared to the top tier universities. In recent years problems with consolidation and rapid growth of the university. Administration has some disagreements and implemented various rules and regulations that limit some students.

job_title: IT Systems Engineer II in Mumbai
pros: Area's largest, most advanced IT infrastructure. Relaxed work pace.  Supervisor very flexible with time off, vacation, etc. Opportunities to learn and develop new skills on the job. Some training. Opportunities at entry level.
cons: Compensation less than industry standards. No salary and merit increases.  Benefits reduced or eliminated over time. Limited advancement for senior professionals. IT operations were outsourced to Cerner 18 months after I departed.

pros: They have a  great environment as well as benefits.  You can always better yourself at the hospital. You can also meet a lot of different people, as well as learning different things.
cons: some of the downsides are from experience. You don't have A lot of team work like there should be in that type of environment. dealing with different professions.

review_title: I enjoyed  30+ year employment including career progression.

cons: Some of the faculties need to be concerned about students working in their labs and make sure the career of student does not get ruined. Augusta is a small town. No party culture. Closest metro city is atlanta which is 2 hours aways.

pros: None. Pay is low benefits are to high compared to pay.
cons: Low pay. Low moral. Horrible management. Hard to move up in company get corned in positions. Management makes it difficult to excel.

pros: Great benefits, most staff are helpful and work well together
cons: Understaffed; patient to nurse ratio is 6:1 a lot of times with pct or cna staff understaffed as well. Not safe for patients or staff

review_title: fish rots from the head down - the child care center review
pros: It is an OK way to get experience. Most of the people there are good to work with. Director is the exception.
cons:
Upper management is very inexperienced and unappreciative. Director is ridiculous, she will blame you for her mistakes and expect you to say nothing. She comes off initially as nice but she is really not. Nobody respects her. She doesn't do her job, she is rarely there to talk to.  High turnover, personnel leave angry. 
Lack of appreciation/incentives for going above and beyond.

review_title: Look into Life in AU Research

cons: Communication can be poor at times. Some departments do communicated with all levels of employees great, but others are not as great.

job_title: Senior Sterile Supply Specialist in Augusta, GA
pros: Wonderful, new facility. Atmosphere is friendly and enjoyable!
cons: Parking is an absolute NIGHTMARE! Literally, this is the only Con working for Augusta University. They expect you to park BLOCKS away from where you work, often times crossing busy intersections! Employees do not feel valued or respected due to this. Parking just a short distance from your office is a BASIC courtesy. For this, I can only grant a 3 star rating.

pros: The university is so big, that the opportunities for you to grow are endless.
cons: The parking is horrible.  You never know who you may end up working for as far as supervisors go.  You could end up transferring to another department and end up working for someone who makes your time for the company horrible.  A horrible boss will make you want to leave the whole institution.

review_title: Pretty good place to gain valuable experience.
pros: Teaching hospital...so great place to learn lots. Mostly good coworkers. Residents are awesome.
cons: Random name changes of school &hospital leaves community confused. Management needs better managing. Staffing issues (frequently not enough nurses based on number & acuity of patients) puts staff and patients at risk.

pros: hard worker, work on time, skilled worker, knowledge based worker, work well with others, work well by myself, made 100% on all of my audits and no criticals
cons: none none none none none none none none none none none none none none none none none none none none except you must work and be aware of your surroundings

pros: American mobile is a great company to work. Fast and efficient service and great customer Values and support. They are there when you need them and take the time to resolve all your needs. Love them
cons: There is nothing bad to say about American Mobile they are excellent.

review_title: Good place but only the Big Wigs are Necessary

cons:

review_title: Fine If You're Living a Home with Your Parents, Or otherwise not paying bills
pros: Experience, If GPA is sufficent enough you can keep the job throughout school
cons: Stressful during the academic year, very demanding despite taking classes, tend to want you to put more emphasis in work than in class at times, feel underappreciated.

pros: Good instructors, knowledgable medical and health care professionals
cons: Red tape is a huge problem. I've never had to deal with such a cumbersome bureaucracy before. You have to leverage your social network to get anything done. If you're new, this is a huge problem. A lot of changes in senior management.

pros: Pay is better than other area hospitals...but even that is not enough to make up for incorrigible management staff.
cons: Management...from the CEO down. I don't believe that all management have always been this bad. Everyone seems to be desperate to keep their positions at this point, so they throw their employees under the bus whenever necessary.

pros: Great place for opportunities to improve skills and receive new training.  Love the investment in middle management.
cons: Arrogant Faculty, Unrealistic expectations of hourly staff, no accountability from the top.

pros: Great work and learning environment. Attendings are approachable and enthusiastic about teaching. Residents all pretty much get along and some become very good friends. Positive environment for growth.

Clinic can be somewhat of a hassle as far as work flow sometimes.
If you are used to big cities you may miss some of the perks of that.
